settings.title: HOW TO HEAL CHAPPED LIPS OVERNIGHT
1. Hydrate from within
settings.desc: Chapped lips are dry lips, so start by making sure you are drinking enough water throughout the day. Avoid drinking hot tea and coffee, as they can both weaken the lipid barrier and act as a diuretic, leading to more dehydration.

settings.title: 2. Don’t lick your lips
settings.desc: Resist the urge to chew and lick dry lips as saliva evaporates, leading them to become even drier. And definitely do not pick at them; this will cause far more irritation, and definitely extend the healing time.

settings.title: What products should I avoid if I want to keep my lips moisturized?
settings.desc: “I would highly recommend avoiding things like retinals and aggressive exfoliators,” says Scott. “Active products are really great for the face, but they can be too harsh for the lips. I usually recommend applying a lip balm onto your lips first and then applying your more active products, avoiding the lips as you would the eye area. By doing that you're minimizing the drying and more abrasive effects of those products.”

settings.title: 3. Exfoliate
settings.text_center:
The first step to healing chapped lips is to gently slough off any flakes and dead skin. This will not only improve the appearance of dry lips and increase blood flow which delivers nutrients to the skin, but also allow your lips to really soak up the benefits of any treatment products. "When treating my clients, I am constantly working on the lip area and always include the vermilion border (the area around the lip line)," Mari shares. "I exfoliate with extremely light microdermabrasion to remove dead skin cells and really lock in hydration with oxygen and LED light therapy."

For an easy DIY exfoliator perfect for lips, simply mix two tablespoons of granulated sugar with half a teaspoon of honey (preferably manuka) and a dash of olive oil.

settings.title: 4. Use a lip treatment
settings.desc: Look for lip treatments that contain ingredients that soothe, heal and moisturize and are free of fragrances or flavorings that can irritate dry, chapped lips. During the day, reapply every two hours as our mouths are constantly moving meaning the product will be absorbed quicker as well as disappear faster. At night, apply a thick layer last thing before bedtime to create an occlusive barrier while you sleep, such as Rose Inc's new Lip Treatment Hydrating Lip Balm.

settings.title: 5. Sleep with a humidifier
settings.desc: Skin naturally loses water content in a dry environment and is able to retain hydration more effectively in a humid one, even absorbing moisture from the air. If you are a mouth breather,  this can also lead to dry lips, and a humidifier can help to reduce congestion in the nasal passage and make it easier to breathe through your nose.

settings.title: Why is licking your lips bad for your lips?
settings.desc: “When you lick your lips you coat them with saliva. Saliva contains digestive enzymes, like amylase and maltase to digest food in your mouth and can wear down the skin on the lips, which can cause chapping, splitting, flaking or peeling,” explains Gentry.

settings.title: How often should you exfoliate your lips?
settings.desc: “Our lips experience a lot of daily friction in the form of talking and eating,” says Scott. “Because of this it is easy to over exfoliate our lips, so I usually say about once a week is enough.”
